feedback: Strengths: The student was able to maintain a conversation on various topics related to living in Korea, demonstrating a good range of vocabulary for this level, including specific terms like 'Dokoshiwan' and 'graduate school'. The student also showed an ability to engage in a topic and provide personal insights, which is commendable at this level. Weaknesses: There were noticeable issues with grammar control and the use of cohesive devices, which impacted the overall clarity and coherence of the speech. Improving these areas could significantly enhance the student's ability to communicate more effectively and fluently. Additionally, the logical flow of ideas can be improved to make the conversation more coherent and engaging.

sentiment.text: Yeah, exchange.

sentiment.text: So I believe that maybe your parental law.

sentiment.text: No, not at all.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: Well, when I, as part of my masters, I studied Korean language.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: Uh, so no, in the uk.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: Yeah, the university had some Korean language courses.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: Uh, so yeah, my Korean at that time when I was studying hard was okay.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: So when I met them, I spoke some Korean and they were like, okay.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: And the most important thing, I ate all of the food.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: Uh, ah, my father in law has always been very happy because I've always eaten any food he's given me or recommended.

sentiment.text: Uh, even though the food is spicy.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: So when he took me for, uh, some food and I ate it, well, he.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: So yeah, when she passed the test to be, uh, a, you know, public official teacher.

sentiment.speaker: A
sentiment.text: Yeah.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: Job for life.

sentiment.speaker: A
sentiment.text: Yeah.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: That's when I thought, okay, I have to decide, do I move back to the UK or do I get married and stay in Korea?

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: That was a big decision at that time.

sentiment.speaker: A
sentiment.text: What about your, your parents?

sentiment.speaker: A
sentiment.text: Your parents are waiting for you coming back to the uk?

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: Well, kind of, but I mean, I'd lived in the, in the US for, I'd studied in the US for one year and uh, I worked in the US for a couple of summers.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: So they always kind of thought I would try and live abroad.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: And my older sister, um, she's not there.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: I don't know why.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: I looked there.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: Um, my older sister lives in Germany.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: She, uh, moved there straight after high school.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: She became a nanny.

sentiment.speaker: A
sentiment.text: What kind of nanny?

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: Like an au pair, like living with a family, taking care of their child.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: It was a professional opera singer.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: This opera singer was, uh, touring, uh, Europe.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: So she.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: No, no, this professional opera singer, uh, they needed a nanny to live with them and tour around Europe to look after their children.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: So straight after high school, uh, my sister got that job and toured around Germany, Austria, Switzerland looking after these children for this opera singer.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: And then she met a boy from Germany.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: Yeah.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: And she's lived in Munich, uh, since she was 18 years old.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: So already, like, my parents were kind of accepting of their children.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: I have, they're four children.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: My older sister, me, my younger sister and younger brother.

sentiment.speaker: A
sentiment.text: This nice ratio of gender.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: Right.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: And it's girl, boy, girl, boy.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: So the two older ones, we live abroad, and then the two younger ones are, uh, kind of living close to home.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: And they, they look after my parents anyway.

sentiment.speaker: A
sentiment.text: They have that tool still there.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: Uh, if I was the only child, then it would be more pressure to move back to the uk.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: I have a few friends who lived in Korea a long time.

sentiment.speaker: A
sentiment.text: But recently, after about 15 years, they've moved back home because their parents get old.

sentiment.speaker: B
sentiment.text: Parents are in 70s, uh, and they, they feel guilty.

sentiment.text: Uh, it's the same way.

sentiment.speaker: A
sentiment.text: Like the.

sentiment.speaker: B
